meta.content: We study the global synchronization of hierarchically-organized Stuart-Landau oscillators, where each subsystem consists of three oscillators with activity-dependent couplings. We considered all possible coupling signs between the three oscillators, and found that they can generate different numbers of phase attractors depending on the network motif. Here, the subsystems are coupled through mean activities of total oscillators. Under weak inter-subsystem couplings, we demonstrate that the synchronization between subsystems is highly correlated with the number of attractors in uncoupled subsystems. Among the network motifs, perfect anti-symmetric ones are unique to generate both single and multiple attractors depending on the activities of oscillators. The flexible local complexity can make global synchronization controllable.

div.div: We study the global synchronization of hierarchically-organized Stuart-Landau oscillators, where each subsystem consists of three oscillators with activity-dependent couplings. We considered all possible coupling signs between the three oscillators, and found that they can generate different numbers of phase attractors depending on the network motif. Here, the subsystems are coupled through mean activities of total oscillators. Under weak inter-subsystem couplings, we demonstrate that the synchronization between subsystems is highly correlated with the number of attractors in uncoupled subsystems. Among the network motifs, perfect anti-symmetric ones are unique to generate both single and multiple attractors depending on the activities of oscillators. The flexible local complexity can make global synchronization controllable.

Biological and social systems have a hierarchical organization with heterogeneous elements. It is challenging to understand the synchronization behavior of such complex systems. In this study, we demonstrate a simple hypothesis that the local complexity of subsystems can govern their global synchronization. In particular, anti-symmetric couplings between subsystem elements are effective for altering their local complexity. This suggests that the ubiquitous appearance of asymmetric couplings can be an effective strategy to control global synchronization in real-world networks.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

Synchronization is a representative phenomenon of coherence in living systems.
1â3
1. Y. Kuramoto,
Chemical Oscillations, Waves, and Turbulence
(
Springer Berlin Heidelberg
, 1984).
2. A. Pikovsky, M. Rosenblum, and J. Kurths,
Synchronization: A Universal Concept in Nonlinear Sciences
(
Cambridge University Press
,
Cambridge
, 2001).
3. S. Strogatz,
Sync: The Emerging Science of Spontaneous Order
(
Hyperion
,
New York
, 2003).
Rhythms and synchronization of neural activities are necessary for odor discrimination,
4
4. M. Stopfer, S. Bhagavan, B. H. Smith, and G. Laurent, â
Impaired odour discrimination on desynchronization of odour-encoding neural assemblies
,â Nature
390
, 70 (1997).
https://doi.org/10.1038/36335
visual feature integration,
5
5. W. Singer and C. M. Gray, â
Visual feature integration and the temporal correlation hypothesis
,â Annu. Rev. Neurosci.
18
, 555 (1995).
https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev.ne.18.030195.003011
and brain computation,
6
6. A. K. Engel, P. Fries, and W. Singer, â
Dynamic predictions: Oscillations and synchrony in top-down processing
,â Nat. Rev. Neurosci.
2
, 704 (2001).
https://doi.org/10.1038/35094565
but perfect synchronization is not always desirable because sometimes it can be disastrous in mental disorders such as epilepsy.
7
7. P. Jiruska, M. De Curtis, J. G. R. Jefferys, C. A. Schevon, S. J. Schiff, and K. Schindler, â
Synchronization and desynchronization in epilepsy: Controversies and hypotheses
,â J. Physiol.
591
, 787 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1113/jphysiol.2012.239590
Electrical engineers apply desynchronization to implement time division multiple access (TDMA) that prevents message collisions and provides asynchronous sleep cycles for nodes on wireless sensor networks.
8
8. J. Degesys, I. Rose, A. Patel, and R. Nagpal, in
Proceedings of the 6th International Conference on Information Processing in Sensor Networks
(
ACM, Cambridge
,
Massachusetts, USA
, 2007), pp. 11â
20
.
Indeed, considering the enormous number of connections between cells and organs in the body, the apparent independence or desynchronization between rhythms in different organs may be a bigger puzzle rather than their synchronization.
9
9. L. Glass, â
Synchronization and rhythmic processes in physiology
,â Nature
410
, 277 (2001).
https://doi.org/10.1038/35065745
Complex systems sometimes show partial synchronization. Two types of partial synchronizations have been recognized. The
chimera state
shows a spatial separation of synchronized and desynchronized domains,
10
10. D. M. Abrams and S. H. Strogatz, â
Chimera states for coupled oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. Lett.
93
, 174102 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.174102
whereas the
periodic synchronization
shows a temporal alternation between synchronized and desynchronized states.
11,12
11. M. Y. Choi, Y. W. Kim, and D. C. Hong, â
Periodic synchronization in a driven system of coupled oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. E
49
, 3825 (1994).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.49.3825
12. H. Hong, â
Periodic synchronization and chimera in conformist and contrarian oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. E
89
, 062924 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.89.062924

Therefore, context-dependent (de)synchronization and their controllability are necessary to ensure that complex systems function effectively. In particular, to disrupt undesired synchronization, various methods have been proposed. These include simply decreasing interaction strengths to stimulate with a short pulse,
13
13. Y. Zhai, I. Z. Kiss, P. A. Tass, and J. L. Hudson, â
Desynchronization of coupled electrochemical oscillators with pulse stimulations
,â Phys. Rev. E
71
, 065202 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.71.065202
and giving a linear/nonlinear delayed feedback.
14,15
14. M. G. Rosenblum and A. S. Pikovsky, â
Controlling synchronization in an ensemble of globally coupled oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. Lett.
92
, 114102 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.92.114102
15. O. V. Popovych, C. Hauptmann, and P. A. Tass, â
Effective desynchronization by nonlinear delayed feedback
,â Phys. Rev. Lett.
94
, 164102 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.94.164102
However, these schemes have been applied for desynchronization in globally coupled networks. Biological networks are generally more complex. They have (i) hierarchical organizations with local/global coupling,
16â18
16. C. Zhou, L. ZemanovÃ¡, G. Zamora, C. C. Hilgetag, and J. Kurths, â
Hierarchical organization unveiled by functional connectivity in complex brain networks
,â Phys. Rev. Lett.
97
, 238103 (2006).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.238103
17. A. Pikovsky and M. Rosenblum, â
Partially integrable dynamics of hierarchical populations of coupled oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. Lett.
101
, 264103 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.101.264103
18. Y. Kawamura, â
Phase synchronization between collective rhythms of fully locked oscillator groups
,â Sci. Rep.
4
, 4832 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/srep04832
(ii) heterogeneous coupling signs with excitatory/inhibitory connections,
19
19. C. BÃ¶rgers and N. Kopell, â
Synchronization in networks of excitatory and inhibitory neurons with sparse, random connectivity
,â Neural Comput.
15
, 509 (2003).
https://doi.org/10.1162/089976603321192059
and (iii) dynamic coupling amplitudes depending on the activities of network elements.
20
20. V. P. Zhigulin, M. I. Rabinovich, R. Huerta, and H. D. I. Abarbanel, â
Robustness and enhancement of neural synchronization by activity-dependent coupling
,â Phys. Rev. E
67
, 021901 (2003).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.67.021901
Thus, desynchronization may not be a simple task in such complex networks.

Recent studies have investigated the control of (de)synchronization in locally connected networks: introducing more inhibitory couplings can suppress synchronization in complex networks;
21
21. V. H. P. Louzada, N. A. M. AraÃºjo, J. S. Andrade, and H. J. Herrmann, â
How to suppress undesired synchronization
,â Sci. Rep.
2
, 658 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1038/srep00658
tuning coupling phases (or delay) and/or balancing between excitatory and inhibitory nodes can switch between synchronization and desynchronization;
22,23
22. C.-U. Choe, T. Dahms, P. HÃ¶vel, and E. SchÃ¶ll, â
Controlling synchrony by delay coupling in networks: From in-phase to splay and cluster states
,â Phys. Rev. E
81
, 025205 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.81.025205
23. C. Wille, J. Lehnert, and E. SchÃ¶ll, â
Synchronization-desynchronization transitions in complex networks: An interplay of distributed time delay and inhibitory nodes
,â Phys. Rev. E
90
, 032908 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.90.032908
optimizing coupling signs and amplitudes can possibly induce cluster synchronization, in which groups of oscillators are separately synchronized;
24
24. J. Lehnert, P. HÃ¶vel, A. Selivanov, A. Fradkov, and E. SchÃ¶ll, â
Controlling cluster synchronization by adapting the topology
,â Phys. Rev. E
90
, 042914 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.90.042914
and changing mesoscale network motifs can also lead to different synchronization patterns.
25
25. W. Poel, A. Zakharova, and E. SchÃ¶ll, â
Partial synchronization and partial amplitude death in mesoscale network motifs
,â Phys. Rev. E
91
, 022915 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.91.022915

In this study, we consider hierarchically-organized oscillators and their synchronization. A hierarchical organization of heterogeneous subsystems with homogeneous oscillators [Fig.
1(a)
] has been analytically studied.
26,27
26. M. Komarov and A. Pikovsky, â
Dynamics of multifrequency oscillator communities
,â Phys. Rev. Lett.
110
, 134101 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.110.134101
27. M. Komarov and A. Pikovsky, â
Effects of nonresonant interaction in ensembles of phase oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. E
84
, 016210 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.84.016210
Here, we focus on another hierarchical organization of homogeneous subsystems with heterogeneous oscillators [Fig.
1(b)
], because many biological and social systems have the latter hierarchy. The pancreas is composed of islets of Langerhans in which heterogeneous endocrine cells interact with each other;
28
28. H. Hong, J. Jo, and S.-J. Sin, â
Stable and flexible system for glucose homeostasis
,â Phys. Rev. E
88
, 032711 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.88.032711
and a country is composed of cities in which people with different opinions interact with each other.
12
12. H. Hong, â
Periodic synchronization and chimera in conformist and contrarian oscillators
,â Phys. Rev. E
89
, 062924 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.89.062924
With this hierarchy in mind, we propose an effective strategy to control the synchronization between subsystems, based on a simple hypothesis that hierarchical systems become increasingly difficult to generate coherent behavior as the complexity of subsystems increases. We examine how the network motif (coupling signs between oscillators) of a subsystem affects its local complexity and the global synchronization between subsystems. To probe this hypothesis, we formulate a minimal model using coupled Stuart-Landau oscillators and demonstrate that the subsystem complexity can predict the global synchronization of the hierarchical system.

FIG. 1.
Two hierarchical organizations of twelve oscillators. (a) Three heterogeneous subsystems (yellow circles) have distinct oscillators (green, red, and blue circles), but each subsystem has homogeneous oscillators. (b) Four homogeneous subsystems (yellow circles) have the same composition of three heterogeneous oscillators (green, red, and blue circles).

C. Limited predictability of global synchronization by local complexity

The strong correlation between local complexity and global synchronization did not always hold. Strong inter-subsystem couplings, large heterogeneities in intrinsic frequencies, or noisy fluctuations of phases decreased the correlation.

>

supplementary material
). We examined how the inter-subsystem coupling strength affected the correlation between local complexity and global synchronization (Fig.

IV. DESYNCHRONIZATION AND CONTROLLABILITY
Section:

The model of hierarchically networked oscillators showed various degrees of synchronization depending on

For the robust realization of desynchronization, Networks 9 and 10 are conspicuous among the 16 networks, because they have the largest parameter region for desynchronization (Fig.
4
). Simpler systems with only two oscillators had a very limited parameter region for desynchronization (Fig. S1 in
supplementary material
), which prevented the simple system from producing robust desynchronization.

VI. DISCUSSION
Section:

In this study, we introduced a simple but effective way to predict global synchronization of hierarchical systems by analyzing the local complexity of uncoupled subsystems. We considered the hierarchical organization of Stuart-Landau oscillators with activity-dependent couplings. Each subsystem consists of three oscillators that interact with each other positively or negatively. Anti-symmetric couplings between three oscillators are special to generate single and multiple dynamic fixed points depending on the amplitudes of the oscillators. Here, the number of attractors can specify the complexity of subsystems. Then, the local complexity can predict the global synchronization of the hierarchical system.

Among the possible coupling signs between three oscillators in one subsystem, we found that perfect anti-symmetric networks (Networks 9 and 10) are more effective for inducing desynchronization of the whole hierarchical system. However, they can also lead to global synchronization by altering their complexity. The controllability of (de)synchronization may explain why biological networks such as neural networks have asymmetric couplings with excitatory/inhibitory connections. Interestingly, Network 9 is realized in the cellular network of pancreatic islets, critical micro-organs for glucose homeostasis.
28,31
28. H. Hong, J. Jo, and S.-J. Sin, â
Stable and flexible system for glucose homeostasis
,â Phys. Rev. E
88
, 032711 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.88.032711
31. D.-T. Hoang, M. Hara, and J. Jo, â
Design principles of pancreatic islets: Glucose-dependent coordination of hormone pulses
,â PLoS One
11
, e0152446 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0152446
Each islet (subsystem) consists of three endocrine cells (Î±, Î², and Î´ cells). Indeed, the synchronization between islets is an important requirement in glucose metabolism.
33
33. M. G. Pedersen, R. Bertram, and A. Sherman, â
Intra- and inter-islet synchronization of metabolically driven insulin secretion
,â Biophys. J.
89
, 107 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1529/biophysj.104.055681
Our finding may suggest the controllability of inter-islet synchronization.
34
34. B. Lee, T. Song, K. Lee, J. Kim, S. Han, P.-O. Berggren, S. H. Ryu, and J. Jo, â
Phase modulation of insulin pulses enhances glucose regulation and enables inter-islet synchronization
,â PLoS One
12
, e0172901 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0172901
It has been recently demonstrated that the unique symmetry of Network 9 for intra-islet interactions can decrease the superficially wasteful zero-sum activity of counter-regulatory hormones, and also enhance/suppress the synchronization of hormonal secretions between islets under high/normal glucose conditions.
35
35. D.-H. Park, T. Song, D.-T. Hoang, J. Xu, and J. Jo, â
A local counter-regulatory motif modulates the global phase of hormonal oscillations
,â Sci. Rep.
7
, 1602 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-017-01806-0

The predictability of global synchronization by local complexity is, however, limited to weakly-coupled hierarchical systems [Figs. S4(b) and S8 in
supplementary material
], because strong inter-subsystem coupling can generate new attractors and significantly perturb the attractor landscape of uncoupled subsystems. We showed how new fixed points were generated in Network 9 for the case of two subsystems (Fig.
8
), with a detailed analysis in the
Appendix
. Second, we considered the heterogeneity of intrinsic frequencies
Ï
n
Ï
and confirmed that their large heterogeneity can also diminish the predictability (Fig.
7
). Third, we examined the noise effects on the predictability. Unless too strong noise makes the system chaotic, the correlation between local complexity and global synchronization is still intact (Fig.
7
).

Finally, the predictability can also be sensitive to time delays of coupling, because the time delays can change the effective sign of couplings between oscillators. The change in coupling signs implies different network motifs. Therefore, in this study, we did not investigate the effect of time delays, since the implicit change in coupling signs could be mixed with the explicit differences in coupling signs in network motifs.
